articles.headline: Ikea Tries to Build Public Case Against Russian Corruption
articles.snippet: Ikea executives say they tried to outsmart kickback-seeking electric utility workers by hiring power generators. Then they checked their generator bills.
articles.abstract: Ikea executives say they tried to outsmart kickback-seeking electric utility workers by hiring power generators. Then they checked their generator bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Weeks before the opening of its flagship store outside Moscow in 2000, Ikea was approached by employees of a local utility company. If the Swedish retailer wanted to have electricity for its grand opening, it had to pay a bribe.

articles.headline: Seven New Rules for the First-Time Home Buyer
articles.snippet: Stretch financially to buy your first house, so-called experts used to say. No more. A damaged financial system requires new strategies.
articles.abstract: Stretch financially to buy your first house, so-called experts used to say. No more. A damaged financial system requires new strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Too many people bought too much house for too many years.

articles.headline: Around the World, Stock Markets Fell and Rose, Together
articles.snippet: In a volatile environment, the American stock market was one of the least volatile worldwide in the last year.
articles.abstract: In a volatile environment, the American stock market was one of the least volatile worldwide in the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States stock market has just completed its best six months since 1933. From March 9 to Sept. 9, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index leaped by 53 percent.

articles.headline: A Year Later, Little Change on Wall St.
articles.snippet: A regulatory overhaul of the financial industry faces difficulty in Congress, but unless the industry’s risks are addressed they could cause an even bigger crisis.
articles.abstract: A regulatory overhaul of the financial industry faces difficulty in Congress, but unless the industry’s risks are addressed they could cause an even bigger crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street lives on.

articles.headline: U.S. Adds Tariffs on Chinese Tires
articles.snippet: The tariff, which will start at 35 percent this month, is a victory for the United Steelworkers union, a crucial ally in President Obama’s health care overhaul.
articles.abstract: The tariff, which will start at 35 percent this month, is a victory for the United Steelworkers union, a crucial ally in President Obama’s health care overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a break with the trade policies of his predecessor, President Obama announced on Friday night that he would impose a 35 percent tariff on automobile and light-truck tires imported from China.

articles.headline: Lehman Had to Die So Global Finance Could Live
articles.snippet: The Lehman Brothers failure caused a panic that spurred Congress to approve the $700 billion bailout.
articles.abstract: The Lehman Brothers failure caused a panic that spurred Congress to approve the $700 billion bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if they’d saved Lehman Brothers?

articles.headline: Jury Deadlock Ends a Trial Over Merck’s Bone Drug
articles.snippet: Jurors sent the judge desperate hand-scrawled notes saying they were deadlocked over a verdict in the trial, which had been monitored as a bellwether for hundreds of other similar lawsuits against Merck.
articles.abstract: Jurors sent the judge desperate hand-scrawled notes saying they were deadlocked over a verdict in the trial, which had been monitored as a bellwether for hundreds of other similar lawsuits against Merck.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in the first jury trial involving the bone drug Fosamax declared a mistrial on Friday after jurors started sending him desperate hand-scrawled notes saying they were deadlocked over a verdict.

articles.headline: U.S. to Accept Iran’s Proposal to Hold Face-to-Face Talks
articles.snippet: Engaging with Iran would put a senior representative of the Obama administration at the bargaining table, along with emissaries from five other nations.
articles.abstract: Engaging with Iran would put a senior representative of the Obama administration at the bargaining table, along with emissaries from five other nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that the United States would accept Iran’s offer to meet, fulfilling President Obama’s pledge to hold unconditional talks despite the Iranian government’s insistence that it would not negotiate over the future of its nuclear program.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Goodbye, Gobbledygook
articles.snippet: To increase sales, makers of personal computers are promoting what their products can do, not what hardware is inside.
articles.abstract: To increase sales, makers of personal computers are promoting what their products can do, not what hardware is inside.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  For the last 30 years, the computer industry has bragged about its achievements. And when the industry was excited about a breakthrough, it expected  even demanded  that consumers get excited, too. But that less-than-symbiotic relationship may be coming to an end.

articles.headline: Company Kept Kabul Security Contract Despite Record
articles.snippet: A review of documents reveals that the State Department had long known of complaints about ArmorGroup, the contractor chosen to protect its embassy in Kabul.
articles.abstract: A review of documents reveals that the State Department had long known of complaints about ArmorGroup, the contractor chosen to protect its embassy in Kabul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When a security guard at the United States Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, was leaving for breakfast Monday morning, he froze at the sight of a crude poster of a rat hanging on his door.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Tales From Lehman’s Crypt
articles.snippet: A look at how some of the people who worked at Lehman have fared since the firm’s sudden collapse a year ago.
articles.abstract: A look at how some of the people who worked at Lehman have fared since the firm’s sudden collapse a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOM OLLQUIST remembers Sept. 9, 2008  the day Lehman Brothers laid him off  as if it were yesterday. “You’re not going to believe it,” he told his wife. “I was shot.”
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Clean Water Laws Are Neglected, at a Cost in Suffering
articles.snippet: In the past five years, companies and workplaces have violated pollution laws more than 500,000 times. But most polluters have escaped punishment.
articles.abstract: In the past five years, companies and workplaces have violated pollution laws more than 500,000 times. But most polluters have escaped punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Hall-Massey knows not to drink the tap water in her home near Charleston, W.Va.

articles.headline: In Wisconsin, Hopeful Signs for Factories
articles.snippet: After months of anxiety about the Great Recession, a bellwether plant saw enough new orders to justify hiring.
articles.abstract: After months of anxiety about the Great Recession, a bellwether plant saw enough new orders to justify hiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEQUON, Wis.  At the Rockwell Automation factory here, something encouraging happened recently that might be a portent of national economic recovery: managers reinstated a shift, hiring a dozen workers.

articles.headline: A Legal Battle: Online Attitude vs. Rules of the Bar
articles.snippet: Lawyers, whose freedom to criticize courts is limited by conduct codes, face special risks when using social media.
articles.abstract: Lawyers, whose freedom to criticize courts is limited by conduct codes, face special risks when using social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sean Conway was steamed at a Fort Lauderdale judge, so he did what millions of angry people do these days: he blogged about her, saying she was an “Evil, Unfair Witch.”

articles.headline: Big Spenders? They Wish
articles.snippet: Even before the recession hit, many lived beyond their means because incomes have fallen as the costs of middle-class American life have risen.
articles.abstract: Even before the recession hit, many lived beyond their means because incomes have fallen as the costs of middle-class American life have risen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have lost homes, jobs and savings to the financial crisis and recession. While greed and extravagance played roles, many lived beyond their means because their paychecks shrank. This article is adapted from “Past Due: The End of Easy Money and the Renewal of the American Economy,” by Peter S. Goodman, a reporter for The New York Times. The book, to be published Tuesday by Times Books, explores the origins of the crisis and suggests ways to reinvigorate the economy.

articles.headline: But Who Is Watching Regulators?
articles.snippet: The financial arena still operates the same and is supervised the same one year after the crisis.
articles.abstract: The financial arena still operates the same and is supervised the same one year after the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOTHING succeeds like failure, as the saying goes. And nowhere is this dismal truth more evident than in our financial regulatory system, one year after the bankruptcy filing of Lehman Brothers.

articles.headline: U.S. to Expand Detainee Review in Afghan Prison
articles.snippet: The Obama administration plans to issue new guidelines aimed at giving the hundreds of prisoners at Bagram Air Base more ability to challenge their custody, officials say.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration plans to issue new guidelines aimed at giving the hundreds of prisoners at Bagram Air Base more ability to challenge their custody, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration soon plans to issue new guidelines aimed at giving the hundreds of prisoners at an American detention center in Afghanistan significantly more ability to challenge their custody, Pentagon officials and detainee advocates say.

articles.headline: Norman Borlaug, Plant Scientist Who Fought Famine, Dies at 95
articles.snippet: A Nobel Peace Prize winner, Dr. Borlaug developed high-yielding crop varieties that helped to avert famines worldwide.
articles.abstract: A Nobel Peace Prize winner, Dr. Borlaug developed high-yielding crop varieties that helped to avert famines worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Norman E. Borlaug, the plant scientist who did more than anyone else in the 20th century to teach the world to feed itself and whose work was credited with saving hundreds of millions of lives, died Saturday night. He was 95 and lived in Dallas.

articles.headline: China Moves to Retaliate Against U.S. Tire Tariff
articles.snippet: China took steps toward imposing tariffs on U.S. automotive products and chicken meat in response to American tariffs on tires.
articles.abstract: China took steps toward imposing tariffs on U.S. automotive products and chicken meat in response to American tariffs on tires.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  China unexpectedly increased pressure Sunday on the United States in a widening trade dispute, taking the first steps toward imposing tariffs on American exports of automotive products and chicken meat in retaliation for President Obama’s decision late Friday to levy tariffs on tires from China.

articles.headline: Miley Cyrus Is on the Line Just for You
articles.snippet: SayNow connects stars and their fans through voice mail and is gaining traction, particularly among teenage audiences.
articles.abstract: SayNow connects stars and their fans through voice mail and is gaining traction, particularly among teenage audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  That hoariest of social networking devices  the telephone  is making a comeback among Hollywood marketers.

articles.headline: After Safe Exit, a Journalist Returns
articles.snippet: In 2008, Thomas Moran, then a political columnist, took a nice offer from PSEG. Now he is heading back into the burning building that is modern journalism.
articles.abstract: In 2008, Thomas Moran, then a political columnist, took a nice offer from PSEG. Now he is heading back into the burning building that is modern journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in February 2008, Thomas Moran, then the politics columnist for The Star-Ledger of Newark, surveyed the brushfire overtaking newspapers and decided it was time to leave the building. With two children approaching college and a spouse, Mary Jo Layton, who also worked in journalism, at The Record of Hackensack, N.J., he decided to take a nice offer from PSEG, a holding company that includes the public utility Public Service Electric and Gas, as a policy director.

articles.headline: Ad Shift Throws Blogs a Business Lifeline
articles.snippet: Blog networks like Gawker are reporting ad revenue is up this year, even as their glossy competition suffers.
articles.abstract: Blog networks like Gawker are reporting ad revenue is up this year, even as their glossy competition suffers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Lisa Sugar began blogging about celebrity gossip in her spare time four years ago. Now she and her husband, Brian, have a little media empire called, sensibly enough, Sugar Inc., with 12 blogs, 11 million readers a month and advertisers like Chanel and Sony.

articles.headline: BusinessWeek, on the Block and Ailing
articles.snippet: In a tough year for sellers of media outlets, there is cautious investor interest in the magazine, and bids are due Tuesday.
articles.abstract: In a tough year for sellers of media outlets, there is cautious investor interest in the magazine, and bids are due Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Numbers sometimes tell a story. And the figures for BusinessWeek suggest it is having one tough time.

articles.headline: Resolve of West Bank Settlers May Have Limits
articles.snippet: Ideological settlers are unlikely to engage in organized armed conflict with the Israeli military, as some fear, because their beliefs make them hesitant to turn against their own.
articles.abstract: Ideological settlers are unlikely to engage in organized armed conflict with the Israeli military, as some fear, because their beliefs make them hesitant to turn against their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVAT GILAD, West Bank  Of the hundreds of thousands of Israeli settlers in the West Bank, those who live in unauthorized hilltop outposts like this one, a hardscrabble unpaved collection of 20 trailers, are considered the most dangerous.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Same Old Hope: This Bubble Is Different
articles.snippet: Risk-taking behavior is beginning to gain traction again as investors look for double-digit returns from the next big thing.
articles.abstract: Risk-taking behavior is beginning to gain traction again as investors look for double-digit returns from the next big thing.
articles.lead_paragraph: This time is different.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Finding Its Role in Business Hard to Unwind
articles.snippet: A call for more oversight comes as government spending accounts for a bigger share of the nation’s economy than at any time since World War II.
articles.abstract: A call for more oversight comes as government spending accounts for a bigger share of the nation’s economy than at any time since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama travels to Wall Street on Monday to speak from Federal Hall, where the founders once argued bitterly over how much the government should control the national economy, he is likely to cast himself as a “reluctant shareholder” in America’s biggest industries and financial institutions.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and David E. Sanger
